references:
Classification performance.
Table¬†I shows the top-1 test accuracy for all FL baselines under Non-IID settings.
For CIFAR-100-Coarse/Fine dataset, we can observe that Cyclic+FedAvg greatly beat four basic FL algorithms. For CIFAR-100-Coarse with Œ≤=0.5ùõΩ0.5\beta=0.5, Cyclic+FedAvg outperforms FedAvg, FedProx, SCAFFOLD, and Moon by 9.63%percent9.639.63\%, 9.74%percent9.749.74\%, 11.91%percent11.9111.91\%, and 10.18%percent10.1810.18\%, respectively.
For CIFAR-10, we can observe that SCAFFOLD consistently outperforms other methods, including Cyclic+FedAvg. Since our method is a pre-training process to initialize the global model, the higher classification accuracy of SCAFFOLD compared to Cyclic+FedAvg is not against the effectiveness of cyclic training.

S4.T2.caption: TABLE II: Comparison of test accuracy improvements
S4.T2.table:
Algorithms Accuracy (%)
w/o Cyclic+ w/ Cyclic+
FedAvg 53.22 57.9157.91\mathbf{57.91}(+4.69)
FedProx 52.88 57.7257.72\mathbf{57.72}(+4.84)
Moon 52.27 57.8957.89\mathbf{57.89}(+5.62)
SCAFFOLD 60.14 60.4760.47\mathbf{60.47}(+0.33)
references:
Table¬†II compares the accuracy of Cyclic+Y, where Y represents FL baselines (FedAvg, FedProx, SCAFFOLD, and Moon). We can find that cyclic training is compatible with these representative FL algorithms, and it improves classification accuracy on FedProx, Moon, and SCAFFOLD by 4.84%percent4.844.84\%, 5.62%percent5.625.62\%, and 0.33%percent0.330.33\%, respectively. Figure¬†3 presents the learning curves of Cyclic+Y experiments.
The four FL algorithms are depicted with dash-dotted lines, and their Cyclic+ versions are plotted in solid lines.
For the Fashion-MNIST dataset, the cyclic training consistently outperforms all baselines.
For FEMNIST, the superior of SCAFFOLD compared to Cyclic+FedAvg has the same reason we explained for CIFAR-10.
For Shakespeare, Cyclic+FedAvg improves prediction accuracy against FedAvg, FedProx, and SCAFFOLD by 0.7%percent0.70.7\%, 10.31%percent10.3110.31\%, and 0.6%percent0.60.6\%, respectively.

references:
Convergence performance.

Table¬†III presents the maximum accuracy and the number of training rounds consumed to achieve it for all baselines. The number of training rounds is underlined for better visualization. We can find that cyclic+fedAvg achieves the highest accuracy in most cases while maintaining the smallest communication rounds consumed.
For experiments including CIFAR-10 with Œ≤=0.5ùõΩ0.5\beta=0.5, CIFAR-10 with Œ≤=1.0ùõΩ1.0\beta=1.0, CIFAR-100-Fine with Œ≤=0.5ùõΩ0.5\beta=0.5, and CIFAR-100-Fine with Œ≤=1.0ùõΩ1.0\beta=1.0, we can observe a tremendously fast convergence speed when starting training from a cyclic pre-training global model: 777 more rounds are consumed to achieve an accuracy of 61.08%percent61.0861.08\%; 292929 more rounds to achieve an accuracy of 61.45%percent61.4561.45\%; 505050 more rounds to achieve 58.92%percent58.9258.92\%; and 282828 more rounds to achieve 58.33%percent58.3358.33\%. For FEMNIST dataset, we can find that it only consumes 171717 more rounds to achieve an accuracy of 84.62%percent84.6284.62\%.
In Figure¬†4, we showed the learning curves of experiments on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100. The first 100100100 rounds represent the cyclic training process, and we switched to P2 to complete the rest of the training process (900900900 rounds).
In this figure, we can observe a notable accuracy leap that occurs after switching to P2, which shows the ability of cyclic training to accelerate convergence.

S4.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Comparison of communication overhead.
references:
Communication efficiency.
We use notations ùêóùêó\mathbf{X}, Tc‚Äãy‚Äãcsubscriptùëáùëêùë¶ùëêT_{cyc}, Tt‚Äão‚Äãtsubscriptùëáùë°ùëúùë°T_{tot}, ùí¶P‚Äã1subscriptùí¶ùëÉ1\mathcal{K}_{P1}, and ùí¶P‚Äã2subscriptùí¶ùëÉ2\mathcal{K}_{P2} to represent the capacity of a model, the number of training rounds in P1, the number of training rounds in P2, the number of local clients in P1, and the number of local clients in P2, respectively.
We denote Tr‚Äãe‚Äãs=Tt‚Äão‚Äãt‚àíTc‚Äãy‚Äãcsubscriptùëáùëüùëíùë†subscriptùëáùë°ùëúùë°subscriptùëáùëêùë¶ùëêT_{res}=T_{tot}-T_{cyc} to simplify symbols.
The overall communication overhead is contributed by training in P1 and P2. In P1, the overhead is controlled by model transmitting between the cloud server and local clients. Two model transmissions are required in each round, leading to a communication consumption of 2ùí¶P‚Äã1‚Äãùêósubscriptùí¶ùëÉ1ùêó\mathcal{K}_{P1}\mathbf{X} in one training round. Therefore, the overall overhead is 2ùí¶P‚Äã1‚ÄãTc‚Äãy‚Äãc‚Äãùêósubscriptùí¶ùëÉ1subscriptùëáùëêùë¶ùëêùêó\mathcal{K}_{P1}T_{cyc}\mathbf{X} in P1. For different FL methods, FedAvg consumes 2ùí¶P‚Äã2‚ÄãTc‚Äãy‚Äãc‚Äãùêósubscriptùí¶ùëÉ2subscriptùëáùëêùë¶ùëêùêó\mathcal{K}_{P2}T_{cyc}\mathbf{X}, FedProx and Moon consume the same as FedAvg does. SCAFFOLD demands uploading control variables, thus leading to an overhead of 4 ùí¶P‚Äã2‚ÄãTc‚Äãy‚Äãc‚Äãùêósubscriptùí¶ùëÉ2subscriptùëáùëêùë¶ùëêùêó\mathcal{K}_{P2}T_{cyc}\mathbf{X} in P1. The communication overhead in P2 depends on which FL algorithm is selected to continue the training procedure. In Table¬†IV, we presented a comprehensive comparison of communication consumption.
